Summarize (Orchestrating the Discussion)

Discussing Solutions and Strategies

The Summarize should focus on how the tape diagram (pictures of segments of smoothie bars) can be used to find equivalent ratios.

Begin the Summarize by asking students to describe and show the ways in which they used pictures of the smoothie bars to find equivalent ratios. Students may have used the pictures in two different ways. The strategies involve scaling the ratios to difference numbers of segments that Sofia and Dembe could share. (Portrayal)

Strategy 1

The following diagram illustrates scaling up a ratio by keeping the size of the bar the same. Each segment is partitioned into more pieces to show equivalent ratios.

• Strategy 2
  • The following diagram illustrates scaling up a ratio by keeping the size of the segment the same. Each bar is repeated to create equivalent ratios.

Strategy 3

The following diagram illustrates scaling up by keeping the size of the segment the same. Each abr consists of more segments with the same relationship to show equivalent ratios.

With ratios, the size or the number of whole smoothie bars can change as long as the relationship between the two quantities does not change. This is one of the ways that ratios differ from fractions. With a ratio of 2 to 1, there can be multiple smoothie bars as long as the relationship between the amounts stays the same, i.e., Sofia always gets twice Dembe's amount.

Making the Mathematics Explicit

Help students see how the strategies emphasized in Problem 2.1 (factor and multiple relationships), Problem 2.2 (tables of ratios), and Problem 2.3 (tape diagrams), all represent ways to use multiplicative reasoning to find and make sense of equivalent ratios.

Suggested Question

  • How do our diagrams of giant smoothie bars relate to tables of equivalent ratios or other ways that we have found equivalent ratios?
• The pictures give a visual of what is happening when we scale up or scale down ratios.

Check for Understanding

Put up four posters, and using the Chalk Talk strategy, have students respond to the prompts silently.

  • Give an example of a comparison statement.
  • Describe the term equivalent ratio.
  • Explain what you think a ratio is.
  • How can you use ratios to solve problems?
